reviewText: The Wire is the best show in TV, I been watching it since season 1 and each season gets better and better. I'm glad HBO is finally bringing season 3 to DVD. I have the 1st 2 on DVD and can't wait to add this to my collection. To fully appreciate season 3 you should watch the 1st 2 seasons or you will be missing a lot of the story and why certain things are happening. Season 3 focuses back on Avon Barksdale who is released from prison and Stringer Bell his lieutant who was holding it down while he was locked up. Omar is still out to get Stringer and Avon for what they did to his boyfriend Brandon in season 1 and all have to say is you have to watch season 3, the end of the show will truly shock you. Great acting by all the actors, great story can wait for season 4. The Wire is the reason I have HBO.

It seems like the best shows take forever to come to DVD. The Wire is the best show HBO has ever done and I know that's a big deal. I say this because no other show has such a depth in character. Every character has a certain duality and I mean every charater. I'll admit that I'm the type who likes to cheer for the bad guys and the problen with most TV shows within the crime genere is that they favor the good guys too much and it gets boring. On the Wire the line between good and bad isn't all that clear to begin with because at some point everybody is human. Most shows are black and white with a small grey area but the Wire has chosen to function entirely in the grey area and that's what makes it so good.
Of course I have my favorite characters but honestly I love them all. The ones that really stand put to me are "Stringer Bell, because he's so smooth...even when he's slippin'" "Brother Mouzone, the Nation of Islam hitman who might just be the scariest dude on the show" and McNaulty which surprises me because normally a crusading good guy character like him will eventually wear thin, but you can't help but like the guy.
Those charaters are some of my favorites but like I said every character in the show gives you a reason to feel somthing for them.
Season three doesn't miss and I suggest you get the first two seasons before you watch this one. The Wire is like a good series of books so start at the beginning and work you way to season 3

The Wire gets better with each season.  Without a doubt, it is the best show on TV.

Season 3 has it all: great writing, great acting, and the best story of the entire series. If you love the Wire, you must get this.

HBO have at long last, decided to release this on DVD and thank goodness. The Wire is undoubtedly the best TV around these days since "Homicide: Life on the Street". No surprise then, I guess that the same man (David Simon) had/has a big hand in both series.

Unlike most crime/cop shows that have a beginning, middle and end in the one episode, the story here is spread over the entire series. We're seeing stuff that kicked off in Season 1 still developing in Season 3. Some viewers find this challenging - this certainly isn't a show you can watch while cooking dinner or chatting to your buddies on the phone. It's sad that ratings have dropped though because if you give the show the undivided attention it deserves and focus on the story, complex as it is, the rewards are truly immense.

After the drama on the docks that was the main focus of Season 2, Season 3 takes it back to the streets where we most like it. The Baltimore drug wars rage on, with Avon Barksdale, played by Wood Harris, out of jail to find his territory of corners under threat from young & ruthless upstart, Marlo, played utterly convincingly by Jamie Hector. Stringer Bell has held things down while Avon's been away but his methods have been questionable, to put things mildly. Stringer gets his comeuppance this season though and as much as I hated the character - and admired Idris Elba for playing it so well - I honestly didn't see his comeuppance coming in the way it eventually did. Scorching scriptwriting!

The police are desperately trying to keep up. Major "Bunny" Colvin, played by Robert Wisdom, comes up with the 'brilliant' idea of creating a 'safe zone' for drug sale and use in the city and this area gets dubbed Amsterdam. The plan seems to work - the rest of the city suddenly becomes a haven - but Colvin keeps the project from his superiors. The results are disastrous, for him and for the city.

Meanwhile, the detail is back on the hunt and as we watch them chase their tails, the questions left hanging in the air are what is this so-called war on drugs about, exactly? And who is winning?

In the background, meanwhile, there's scheming, wrangling and backstabbing in the corridors of the city political powers. Unlike the stuff on "The West Wing" this is the kind of politics I can get into and this is a story that is going to run and run.

Like any TV show, this one has its 'stars' but this is truly an ensemble performance. Everyone, whether it's by playing a starring role, a recurring role, bit part or even an extra, gets to contribute a crucial part of the jigsaw that makes up the big picture.

Still, I must mention some of my favourite performers. Apart from those already mentioned, they include: Lance Reddick, an actor with the ability to convey more with a single look than most actors can with a whole minute of dialogue, as Lieutenant Daniels; Dominick West, who plays Detective Jimmy McNutly, a cop who races to save the world while his own life crumbles around him; Sonja Sohn, who plays Detective Kima Greggs, McNulty's loyal partner, who realises she's not as ready for a life of domesticity with her girlfriend and their baby as she had originally thought; Andre Royo, who plays Bubbles the 'co-operative' drug fiend with heart; Michael K. Williams, who plays Omar the gay gangster with a shotgun - something I never thought I'd see on TV in my lifetime; Frankie Faison and John Doman who play Commissioner Burrell and Deputy Commissioner Rawls respectively (for some reason, neither fails to make me laugh out loud with every line they deliver); Michael Hyatt, who plays Brianna Barksdale, mother of D'Angelo (who was murdered in Season 2) and sister to kingpin Avon; and last but by no means least, the 'dynamic' duo Detectives Herc and Carver, played wonderfully by Dominick Lombardozzi and (the beautiful) Seth Gilliam respectively.

And then there's Chad L. Coleman as Dennis "Cutty" Wise, the ex-con who finds he no longer has the stomach for the streets. He turns to volunteering, running a youth boxing gym. Here's an actor to look out for and he brings an intensity to his role that I found mesmerising. I hope we get to see more of him in future Seasons.

This is a totally believable drama with cracking dialogue and nary a cliche or stereotype to be seen. The reactions to the show, both positive and negative just go to show how a gritty and realistic drama series can hit home.

This is a must for any connoisseur of mature and thought provoking TV. This is one show that takes a long, unapologetic and uncompromising look at an underclass we would all prefer to ignore and thus, while it's not always pretty, it is always riveting. If you don't have seasons 1 & 2, I recommend you get them now. This one of very few shows I am able to watch over and over and not get bored, learning and appreciating something new each time. I am placing my pre-order for Season 3 forthwith!

I watched Seasons 1 & 2 again last week and came to the realization that it was the best show on HBO. I used to have Sopranos in my top spot, but the Wire has passed it. It has the patience and intelligence I wish the Sopranos could consistently maintain. However, the Wire has only had three seasons and the Sopranos six, so it is might be harder for Chase and crew.

Season Three picks up where Season 2 left off with Daniel's new team investigating the dope in Baltimore. Like the two previous seasons having a theme (1-streets & police, and 2-dock workers and smuggling) this season involves the politics.

Season 2 is still my favorite, but all three seasons are amazing. The third continues the standards of the previous two seasons with excellent writing, acting, and pacing. Robert Wisdom who potrays Major Colvin and Aidan Gillen who plays Councilman Thomas 'Tommy' J. Carcetti  are excellent new additions who hold their own to an exellent ensemble.

Thank you HBO for making a 4th Season, despite lower ratings. The critics are right, this is the best drama on TV.

The Wire is a gritty and gripping detective drama, which is widely considered to be one of the all-time best shows in this genre, as well as being one of the greatest television programs ever made. It was created and primarily written by David Simon, the renowned author and former crime reporter, who, because of his background, was able to impart an uncanny sense of realism to the series. The Wire was set and produced in Baltimore, Maryland, and its story line centers around the organization and function of the criminal drug trade in Baltimore, and the tragic way in which it has ravaged the city, and its beleaguered residents. The Wire consists of a total of sixty episodes, spanning five seasons, with a different emphasis for each season. Although the multifaceted drug trade represents the overarching focus of this series, each individual season assesses the manner in which this criminal enterprise impacts a specific operational area of the city of Baltimore. The first season of The Wire examines the drug trade itself, the second season deals with the dysfunctional seaport system, the third season analyzes the corrupt city government and bureaucracy, the fourth season addresses the deteriorating school system, and the fifth and final season evaluates the unethical print news media. It brutally and realistically depicts the devastating effects that the criminal narcotic trade has had on the residents of inner city Baltimore, whose lives have been destroyed by the pervasive drug-related misery, despair, and hopelessness, which have now become endemic in this population. The Wire is characterized by insightful and brilliant writing, superb plot and character development, and absolutely spectacular acting performances, by its exceedingly talented ensemble cast. It definitely deserves the numerous awards and accolades which it has received over its five-year run. The Wire is a truly outstanding television series, which is riveting, moving, and emotional, and it merits an unequivocal five-star rating, along with a very strong recommendation.

Man this show was a masterpiece. Greatest show ever!

THE WIRE is STILL one of the best HBO series ever made, and that's saying something, since HBO has produced so much good TV. What is remarkable  is the depth and breadth of the series. At the center is a small group of cops concentrated on drug gangs in Baltimore. As the series goes on you see gang members as human beings, corruption leading into the city and state governments, unions, and even the department of justice. You also see the venality of police enmeshed in politcs. Senior cops trying to show good statistics for their command as the city continues to deteriorate. And yes, there are plenty of characters to like. Men and women trying to do their work with integrity against the odds. If you've never seen it, watch it. If it's been a long time, watch it again.

Viewing Season One thru Three. Story line is pretty good if you can handle the gang banging, dope pushing and gay and heterosexual  scenes which were way overplayed. Obvious  are the writers points that seem to be made. The awareness of the political connection and interaction with the crime world is interesting. The insight in the law enforcement life was interesting when revealing their challenges in racial, diverse characters, personal lives and their frustrations in doing their duties. Urban life in the raw...nothing much here that our youth can obtain from the positive interactions. But it was not geared to them but for the Mature audience. I plan on finishing the series. Great selection of actors to tell this tale.

"The Wire" is Shakespearean; truly evil bad guys, semi-good good guys, crisp, colorful dialog and characters who you care about, even the bad guys. "The Wire" is one of my all-time favorite series.

Definitely a highlight season with all of what makes this series a great piece of television history. The ongoing Jimmy McNulty, Bunk, Kima stories continue with quite a few shifts as the impressive Bunny suffers difficulties, Prez endures a true shocker and the second to last show of the season develops out a character in such a shocking way that I can't say anything about it here without being a plot wrecker. But suffice it say, I was really disappointed in that I had no idea how much the character had meant to me over the season. Anyway, hard to discuss without giving it all away, but the typically entertwined series of side plots done so skillfully, make for great viewing and the only reason I gave it 4 instead of 5, is that there were a couple of cliches that didn't need to be.

I feel like the third season of The Wire is one of the most compelling seasons of television I've seen.  In my opinion, the most interesting plotlines, among many, are Bunny Colvin's "free zone", the fight between Marlo and the Barksdale crew after Avon's return and Cutty's attempt to rehabilitate himself and the corner kids through the boxing gym.  I'm not terribly interested in the political thread, but when the interplay between the Barksdale crew and the political institutions goes south, it makes for great TV.

I think "The Wire" is one of the top 5 TV series of all time in terms of the writing, the filming and the accuracy of the depiction.  I watched all 60 episodes over the 5 seasons to understand the story and the characters and then I went back and watched all 60 episodes again to focus on the culture and the values of all the groups -- the police, the organized gangs, the people living in those neighborhoods, the schools, the politicians and so on.  And it's interesting how you come away having empathy for each of those entities while at the same time you see how those various entities are falling short of what they could be doing to help resolve the the disfunction in our inner cities.

From the script to the characters to the direction, "The Wire" exemplifies what American television is capable of creating when great acting, writing, and producing are unfettered.  The humanity of the prototagonists, whether drug dealers, police or politicians, is consistently demonstrated without obscuring their villainy, veniality, or outright stupidity.  Anyone who watches this show will have an excellent insight into the difficulties of addressing inner city problems in America.

This was a show that had it all - an exciting, propulsive plot, fine acting, and superb writing, particularly those episodes scripted by Richard Price. There's one episode with a scene showing a small group of convicts discussing "The Great Gatsby," with Richard Price playing the part of a teacher. Sure, there's the requisite amount of gunplay and savagery, but, after all, the drug trade is not lawn bowling. Although I don't feel that this season is as rich and original in its strory lines as that of Season 2, it's still stunning.

Simply a fine television series. Gritty and sadly realistic, The Wire brings together a collection of talented cast members, amazing writing and direction, and creates a tight story line and a pace that moves perfectly from scene to scene.  No unnecessary cliff hangers, or dramatic pauses to fake hype the scene, just smooth storytelling.  If anyone has debated over whether or not to watch The Wire. Do it - Start season one and commit to watching three episodes.  If you aren't hooked, walk away - no harm no foul. But there is so much depth to the characters - the police, the criminals, the politicians, and all the others that hold Baltimore together, I'm confident that if you start, you will watch all five seasons.

All three seasons are absolutely riveting!  Some of the best acting I've ever seen . . . and from unknowns, back when the show was produced.  Some of the best writing and execution I've ever encountered--characters, plot lines, realistic details, on-the-spot-perfect language and diction for the locations, violent and sexual realism that was necessary for the story, rather than for gratuitous shock value.  The series assumes that the audience is intelligent and doesn't need any coddling, recaps, blatant "spoon-feeding":  the audience needs to pay attention to every single little snippet within an episode: a 10-second section of the story line is just as important as a five-minute focus . . . if you miss it or can't process it, you lose a key part of a future section.  The music is also a "character" and is not used to tweak or manipulate the audience's emotions.  In the end, you feel like you have been right there in the hood or police station, or bar, or house--not observing, but a silent participant.  I recommend the series to somebody almost every day!

They say this is President Obama's favorite show - or one of them. It is my belief that the better tv series are both a commentary on and pleading to society. One way they do this by capturing something elemental in all of human nature in each of the characters so that we identify with all of them to some degree, and eventually see that each of us is part of the whole, all of us are one. In today's reality, I think tv has a role in how we decide determine (or act out) our future. This season left me wondering about the role of hope and whether we are entering into a new dark/middle ages. I thought the way the role of institutional racism was overly dealt with was honest and potentially helpful to society. That conversation is spreading today, and I hope that someday we will have enough comfort and language to speak about it at a wide enough range that we can reform.

The wire is extremely well written, directed and acted. I'm amazed at the authenticity and realism... the show pulls no punches. The producers provide a window into the grittiness of urban life, juxtaposed with violence, humor, despair, and redemption. The Wire offers a poignant, in-your-face portrayal of those involved in drug sales and usage; as well as an in-depth look at the day to day frustrations of the police officers assigned the thankless job of dealing with this impossible situation. Well done!

"The Wire"  All 5 seasons is the BEST Television series ever made.  The series was only nominated for 2 Emmys (both for writing). This is why Hollywood based Emmy Voters said they didn't vote for the series. They couldn't relate to its drug-infested Baltimore milieu, they didn't see the actors and producers around Los Angeles because they shoot on location in Maryland, and the plots are too hard for them to follow.

This series presents Baltimore in 5 different arenas:  Drugs, The Port, Elections, The Schools and The decline of Newspapers.  The writing is phenomenal.  Every actor, whether professional or first time actor, is terrific.  i have watched the whole complete series at least 4 times and every time, I find something new to love about it.
Still very entertaining and well done.  This show is very well written for its multiple character cast.  I like everything about this show from the actors to the great production.

Though not the best season of the series (my opinion), the series overall is one of the few police shows I watched which I felt strongly resembled the politics of real policing. The street cops know what must be done and what leads must be followed to solve a case. But getting from A to Z in a case is plagued by mostly internal politics and self-interest by those all the way up the line. I suppose it resembles life all too often, in that self-serving actions derail duty and nobility of purpose. Any cop has likely seen this, and this show has so many snippets of reality, even in a small agency, such as the line Carver says when he watches some gang-bangers beat up on each other, "You see. This is why we will never win. When they screw up they get beat. When we screw up, we get a pension."

Seeing many unethical things get swept under the carpet, one must learn the reality, "Never let progress get in the way of your politics." Much good work has been stifled and many noble principles ignored to protect the name of the agency or someone standing high in it's ranks. It never seems to be about real accomplishments, just the perception -read "spin"- of accomplishments.

This series is worth every minute spent watching it.

The Wire is, quite frankly, the Greatest Show ever.  Breaking Bad gets its due but it's complete fantasy fiction. The Wire is real, piecing together true stories David Simon witnessed, and wrote about in his Homicide book. But than it's SO much more, the character development, the acting, the dialogue, the true life circumstances of drugs, crime, murder, with the corrupt and innefficient law enforcement run by politicians is the canvas. Brave men and women in the BPD fight against the institutional mayhem, the War on Drugs. The politicians need stats to be elected or re-elected. The results, are terrible and given great treatment in The Wire. Police officers with self awareness love the show too, for its honesty.

  In this season more so than others, the officers themselves are the heroes of the show.  The institutions are the villains. "The Gods" in David Simon's words, The Wire is Greek Tragedy with the heroes fighting against Fate and the Gods. The Gods, are the Institutions of the Modern City.  The BPD. The Gangs. The School System, the Political System.  This season had a very big story about a precinct captain Im not going to name because I don't want anyone googling and spoiling themselves.
Our Democracy, creates so many terrible dilemmas, we all want less drugs, our solutions? Increased suffering, death and prison population.  War on drugs isn't really a war.
 "Why not?" -Herc
"Wars end" - Carver

I liked it in spite of the really, really awful use of profanity.  Also, for the first time (I think) they had almost XXX rated scenes. I was surprised at that.  I could not watch this with my children or my grandchildren - no way!  All that said I think it shows the very evil side of the drug trade by the lowest and mid-level pushers in Baltimore.  This series should be available for responsible adults.  And FINALLY some people - of both colors - who want to improve the lives of the young people in disadvantaged neighborhoods.

The Wire is one of those programs which both gets better and changes as it moves along.  The premise is always the same: A Wiretap.

Season 3 centers in McNulty's obsession in taking down the Barksdale and Bell crews.  The regular crew, Herc and Carver (in diminished roles), Griggs, Sydnor, Prez,  "The Bunk", Pearlman, Sgt. Jay Landsman, Freamon, McNulty, Bubbles and the LT, Cedric Daniels.  This season also introduced Bunny. Major Howard Colvin (Robert Wisdom), the commander of the Westside.  The man who "legalized" drugs in the eyes of the Mayor, Commissioner and Deputy Commissioner.

On the side of the bad guys we have Avon, Stringer, Prop Joe, Omar, Slim Charles, Poot, Bodie, and a slew of red shirts (expendables), Brother Mouzone, a very unique hitman and Sen Clay Davis.

This is all out war for the battle of good and bad.  With the wiretaps in place, even for the limited time with the gangsters using "burners", Freamon and crew.  McNulty being McNulty is so narrow minded that new manages to get himself in trouble over his obsessiveness.

The Wire is a program for serious viewers.  Sure, there's some comedy but this is great drama.

An impressive series! The end of the third season concludes a long narrative which seems to have begun long ago and ends without the usual triumph of good over bad, No one is spared; nor are any of the participants faultless. There's a certain cynicism which pervades "The Wire" and there are no blameless heroes. In many ways, it is not unlike "Spiral", the French series about cops, politicians, and crooks in Paris. Be prepared for coarse language and emotional and physical violence.

My husband and I love they series The Wire. It hits on every great part of a series. On par with the House of Cards series in gripping episodes and you can see how they related specific real life events to what played out in the series.

In Season 3, the action returns to the streets of Baltimore. The most interesting dynamic of this season is the relationship between Avon Barksdale (recently released from prison) & Stringer Bell, his 2nd in command. Avon is still a street thug & wants to battle Marlo Stanfield for the street corners Avon's operation lost when he was in prison. Stinger, however, would rather go legit as both Avon & himself have enough money that they'd never have to go back to the street.

As a retired law enforcement officer, I've found "The Wire" to be quite accurate with its depiction of drug sales, money laundering, etc. Whle we couldn't get away with the "antics" of McNaulty, et al., it was realistic enough to remain captivating. Cannot wait to finish the remainder of the series. Look at in order!

gosh i have put off writing this reviewfor at least a week.  its like this. full disclosure  i own this series on dvd. have owned it for years.  i own all 5 seasons. quite possibly one of the best shows ever televised in the last 20 years. i know the script for this series.  i knew the deacon was an ex drug dealer years before he passed away last week. yes melvin passed last weekend.  season 3 is the culmination of the whole stringer avon barksdale story. when brother muzzone and omar finally see eye to eye one knows stringer is in trouble. this has been a hoot watching this on amazon.  but with honesty i may wait some time before watching season 4.  the only good part of that season is the saving of bubbles.  but for me the main story concludes with the season 3 ending. now marlo takes control.  omar takes lots of druge from the dealers and we spend lots of time in school.  another review for another day peace out

The Wire, Season 3, is both entertaining and depressing. The acting, the writing and the photography are gripping. That's the entertaining part. But the realism of a major American city sinking in a bog of corruption, crime and degradation is shocking and frightening. The same problems destroyed once-magnificent Detroit. While Baltimore's slow death and the attempts of dedicated law enforcement to postpone the end are fascinating television, the underlying truths revealed by The Wire are haunting.

Season 3 of The Wire gets back to focusing on the Barksdale drug organization.  In this season they are forced out of their territory after the city urbanizes the area.  They must take over new territory and deal with rival gangs who are also trying to claim these spots as their own.  Once again the writing of the story is unmatched by any other crime TV show that I have ever seen.  You just cant get this good of a picture of a crime-ridden inner city than what The Wire will give you.  The third season introduces some new storylines as we see how political corruption and money affect the justice system and how unfair some of this stuff can be. The Wire continues to amaze me and is deservedly regarded as one of the greatest TV shows of all-time.

It is about an over zealous city hall, running a city, via its police force, against its apolitical citizens desires.  It is not all black and white; good or evil. There are good and bad guys on both sides.  It showcases the plight of the poor unconnected citizens verses the powerful, political city government.  There is a lot of violence (on both sides); it sets back civil rights decades.  It screams for reform and hope.  If you desire to watch it; fasten your seat belts... you are in for a ride, of your lifetime.

Season 1 was about the pagers and the "Towers".  Season 2 was about the docks and the dead girls in the box.  Season 3 is about Stringer Bell's attempts to go legit (or become and even bigger gangster by playing in the big leagues, perhaps?).  It's also about Hamsterdam, Major Colvin's program to clean up his street corners by declaring an abandoned (mostly) neighborhood an arrest-free zone for drug dealers.  There is a scene in one of the episodes where the Major says that if they don't cooperate there will be 'Old Testament treatment before they even get to the station'.  A chilling example of life imitates art.  On the whole, I haven't found this season, after several episodes, to be quite as compelling as the first two, but, I understand from friends who have viewed the whole series that it's setting the viewer up for bigger dramatic rewards later on.

The Wire remains the most accurate and unvarnished depiction of urban America in Television history. The show is both an artistic masterpiece of cinema in the TV medium and a near-documentary representation of reality on the streets of inner-city America. There has never been a television show that so carefully curates the living history of a major city. The sights, sounds, characters and dialogue are a virtual symphony of urban realism that has never before or after been captured by this medium. Make no mistake, the true star of this show is The City of Baltimore - but then the exact locale of its content is almost irrelevant as its portrayal of urban reality could be any major city in America. The show manages to be prosaic and poetic; canonizing and critical (of city life in Baltimore); objective and editorial; Skakespearean and colloquial. I know of no TV show that has reached such lofty levels of high art while making no compromises in its visceral portrayal of decidedly uncomfortable subject matter (The complex multi-layered problems of urban America).  I've not seen a better television show of any kind than The Wire - period. Bravo! To David Simon and the incredibly skilled writers of this television epic.

on of the greatest shows on TV ever!  It should be required viewing for every social worker, teacher, parent or human being who has any influence over a child and how that child is raised....the main message of this show is what happens to children when their parents are so damaged they cannot do what is in the best interests of the child.  Heart braking to see how human lives are lost due to people not being able to do the right thing.  From the corrupted elected officials, cops who do not do their jobs, mothers who are walking advertisements for "this is what you will become if you do drugs- alcohol etc...and children who want to do the right thing but do not have any support and are pulled into lifestyles they never wanted...it also addresses the horrifying fact that many grow up to be sociopaths and run havoc wherever they go.  Excellent acting, writing and direction...wish it was still on!  Watch and learn.

I watched every season and although I loved some seasons more than others, KEEP WATCHING! It all works together. "The Wire" is quite possibly the best television series ever made. Plot is excellent, acting is spot on, and it's portrayal of how serious and devastating it really is for our inner cities that we have lost the war on drugs is stunning. The premise of this season seems unlikely, that a major unit commander in the Baltimore Police Department would be able to establish a "safe haven" for drug dealing to free up his resources and create a climate in which he could rescue some areas of his district from the ravages of the drug trade. In fact, something like this actually did happen, and the third season is based on a real effort. Because its cast is mostly non-white, it gives the viewer a chance to see some terrific acting from many performers not normally featured in prominent television roles. Some of the cast though have made an impact on TV; Idris Elba went on to star in the BBC's "Luther", Lance Reddick did Lost and Fringe, but my favorite is Wendell Pierce, who plays Det. Bunk Moreland. At any rate, great cast and riveting storyline.

The Wire is a well-done cop series, however, I've given up on it because of the excessive nudity, sex and filthy language. My only observation is that it was chillingly prophetic of the current situation in Baltimore. It is a very realistic view of a city sinking in its own muck and garbage and despair, a city held hostage to socialist welfare and a Democratic strategy to keep blacks down on the plantation  that's the Democrat plantation. It's not "corners" or "free zones" anymore. The reality is mass anarchy, depravity, riots, arson and murder that dramatically demonstrates how Baltimore then came to be Baltimore now. In that respect, it is great drama.

I would like to have given this five stars, as it is a riveting show.  But I find it hard to follow the plot and characters a good bit of the time.  The camera goes from one short scene to the next and characters pop up quickly before it all has time to solidify in my mind.  We watch it with closed captions to we can follow the dialogue better.  All that said the series overall is exceptional.  I thought I'd give it a break for a while before watching Season 4, but I can now find myself actually missing some of the characters and wanting to find out how they are doing and what they are up to....like old friends.
The only other show that really affected me this way was Spiral, a French cops and robbers and lawyers series, which is really really worth a watch for those who like these kinds of series.

This is the best series ever written for viewing.  Why it has not received more recognition by the artistic/acting community is beyond my understanding?  I liked everything about the series--the acting, the story line and, most important, the message it leaves with the viewer.  The depth of understanding of important sectors of the U.S. community--life and education in the inner city, race relations, both heroic actions and corruption in the police department, business community, different levels of government, unions and the media--are compared and contrasted with the profound impact their actions/interactions have on real people lives.  Most of the characters in the series are not one-dimensional, but complicated people, with both strenghts and weaknesses, that you will remember forever.  I am happy to see so many of the actors in so many different movies and series today.  Please make more series like The Wire.

One of the biggest complaints about The Wire presented in an HD format is that the original look and feel of the show is lost due to image cropping at the top and bottom of the screen to make the originally square image fit on a widescreen TV.

I'm a stickler for that sort of thing. And I watched The Wire on HBO when it came out in it's original format. And I didn't even notice the difference. The show transforms to a 16:9 ratio very well without impacting the artistic quality of the series.

So don't hesitate to watch The Wire presented on Amazon in a widescreen format. The quality is great and you'll enjoy the show just as much (or more) than you did the first time you watched it.

Second to only The Sopranos as the best series I've ever watched. I was late to The Wire, but even considering that it was created ten years ago, it is simply incredible drama. Well written with an amazing cast, each show unfolds layers of story lines and characters. My brother-in-law is a Baltimore beat cop and has told me that he is amazed how perfectly depicted the city, police force, crime, and politics are depicted. Season One hooked me, Season Two was less intriguing to me because of the emphasis on politics, but Season Three was captivating. I could not wait to watch the next episode. Stringer Bell and Omar Little are two of the most compelling characters I've ever seen on television. Idris Elba and Michael K. Williams fill up every scene they're in.
The Wire is simply the greatest show to ever be on television. I'd say it gives you the gritty details of how major American cities function.

The one who was smart enough to see that he had to get out found himself at a loss when it came to dealing with recalcitrant construction crews.  Don't miss watching this.  It is good.

Season 3 is arguably the best on "The Wire" series because of the tension illustrated between opposing factions on the same side of a conflict. Bunny Colvin employs an innovative approach to "protect and serve" the people of Baltimore, while delivering the reduction in crime requested by City Hall. Similarly, Stringer Bell brings structure and discipline to the business of selling drugs that achieves the same crime reduction goals wanted by the police and City Hall, but at the risk of tainting the Barksdale reputation. Each side, the law & the lawbreakers, has its innovators and their reactionary detractors. Throughout the season, the audience is chauffeured along a landscape of conflict that ultimately draw us deeper to the characters in advance of a dramatic conclusion. Bravo!

I enjoyed seasons one and two but here it starts going down hill and with all the murder and mayhem I find myself asking, "Who cares?"  Having watched the entire series, I would recommend watching the first two seasons and just stopping.  There are no more conclusions at the end off the series than there are at the end of season two.  They drag in the Baltimore school system, more crooked politicians, and the Sun newspaper for God knows why and he ain't tellin'.  Sub plots are left dangling.  Actions occur for which there is no connection to the plot and yet they are treated as if they are important.  Can't fault the acting.  Actors can only play the script and really using Baltimore for location shooting adds a certain sense of reality.  Only complaint I have there is that the traffic is a whole lot worse than portrayed.  For anyone thinking that the " grittiness" is enhanced, hasn't been to Baltimore.  Detroit and Philadelphia are the only places that are worse in the country.  The political corruption portrayed is very real and applies to the entire state not just Baltimore.  The state  is run on the Bubba system much like Mississippi.  You have white bubbas and black bubbas. but they function on the same level, both being arms of the democratic machine.  Pelosi is an example of Baltimore and Maryland politics, being the daughter and sister of Baltimore mayors.  In their day the connections were with the Mafia rather the drug lords but the politic are the same.  Best advice, stop watching after season two.
The best show on tv

This whole series could be the best dramatic series that TV ever had.  The basic plot follows the "drug war" on the streets of Baltimore and the wire-taps (ie, "The Wire") used to track the drug lords.  Each season has two things that change for that season:
  1) The same theme song is used throughout the 5 seasons ("Way Down in the Hole", written by Tom Waits), but each season it's sung by a different singer/group and in a different style.  In season 3, that's the Neville Brothers.  Can't do much better than that.  And,
 2), Each season focuses on a different facet of Baltimore life and how that affects and is affected by the local drug problem.  In season 3, the show focuses on the city and state politicians...and a nasty bunch they are.  If you want to see how local politicos REALLY run a city, this is the show to watch.

So, if you want  TV drama done as it should be done, stop watching today's so-called "reality shows" and watch real drama.  But start with season 1 and work your way up.  You won't be disappointed.

As with any great TV series, Mad Men included, there comes a time when the franchise loses its story. Perhaps The Wire, given its limited mission, was destined to fall sooner than the others, but season three definitely shows all the signs of a lost story. What was once fun--stake outs, busts and interview room workovers, office politics, power intrigue, McNulty drunkenness--have all become things for cast and crew to do while nothing happens. A shame, but given how the sensational and gritty season two fizzled as it came to a close, this should not have been unexpected.

Another great season for The Wire.  This season revolves around an examination of whether or not "decriminalization" of drugs  might work out if tried.  Instead of the normal debate among talking heads, we're treated to a dramatization of how a possible scenario might play out.  I was especially impressed by the way in which the series avoided the political landmines so common in other series which generally try to sell their point of view.  Season 3 is as well done as the other seasons.

No matter how far out the Wire characters act, they make their psychopathic "business" decisions rationally, whether coldly or hot headed reaction, move and counter move.  There are no fools; no super geniuses; just normal people making sometimes good; sometimes foolish decisions, resulting in planned and unexpected outcomes.  The sub plots as well are thought provoking, and interesting.

They also learn and develop from season to season.  All in all, still the best cop series ever!  The usual 30 or 40 "f" and "n" bombs are in each episode; also, a quick lesbian soft core porn scene appears in one of the latter episodes, as well as an interracial coupling - but for most adults, this remains one of the most rewarding shows you can watch.

Not my favorite season but still amazing. The story of Hampsterdam, while fictional is such an obvious insight into what needs to be tried in the "war on drugs". David Simon is clearly asking, when our current approach is such an obvious failure (in terms of excess prison sentences, havoc wreaked in poor predominantly black communities, and of course addicted users) why can't we try something else? Specifically, he means a type of legalization with addiction treated as the Public Health issue that it really is. Like all the seasons of the wire, this season is sad, poignant, and incredibly entertaining.

Where the storyline was very tight before, in Season Three we loosen up, which makes the show less gripping.  Everyone is in a state of flux, a little lost, from the police task force to Avon's crew to the hoppers and even the characters themselves.  Season Three looks like a transition.  I say this because I haven't seen seasons four or five yet, so I'm being patient.  Still interesting, still fun and unpredictable, but the fast pace has slowed, and there's no telling where things are headed.  It's as if everyone is waiting, including the audience, for the other shoe to drop.

But now that Amazon has the series, and for the best price, I figured, "why not?"
Turns out all the shambling zombies muttering about McNulty and Herc under their breath were right. It's the rare thing that lives up to its hype, and every season of The Wire has done so in spades. One of the best cop dramas ever!  "The Wire" takes place in Baltimore, Maryland and centers on a crack team of law enforcement "leftovers" who are part of a surveillance/wiretapping unit.  Season 3 centers on the new territory disputes between the Barksdale drug empire and a new player on the scene named Marlo Stanfield.  We also start to get a clearer picture of the political backing behind the drug money flowing through the city.  Very gritty and very well performed, this series is for anyone who enjoys a good crime drama but can stomach nudity, graphic violence, hard drug use, and dark urban themes.

The Wire continues to set the bar for exceptional drama; gritty and unflinching, about the only criticism I can make of this show is that if you come to it without watching at least Season One first, you'll quickly find yourself lost in the complex maze of characters and happenings.

As to the show as a whole, I would strongly suggest that if you like Breaking Bad, you will enjoy this show even more.  Why?  Because while BB is a gripping and relentless drama, there still is an air of unreality to it.  The Wire is as close to real as one can get, to the point where it feels like a documentary at times... almost as if you could drive to those streets in Baltimore and see the faces on your TV screen populating the corners.  And the storylines are just as compelling and involving as those of Breaking Bad.

As for the casting, I have never seen a collection of such good actors: quite literally, I can't think of an actor who seemed miscast.
So-
Story: A+
Casting: A+
Acting: A+
Direction: A+

...I literally can't think of a better show.  Breaking Bad is a close, close second, but The Wire is simply the best show I've ever seen on TV.

And the gratuitous pornography seals that limitation. The obligation writers and producers feel to leave no aspect of sexual situations or violence to the imagination in the process further limits the viewership of an otherwise well-written and well-played police procedural series.
Love the first season

One thing I love about the first two seasons of The Wire is the intense focus on character, and how individuals and relationships drive the activities on both sides of the law. And one thing that disappoints me about Season 3 is that the show seems to be tipping into soap opera territory, where the hookups and the back-stabbing are the story, rather than the context for a story about drug dealers and investigators. So, I took a star away from my earlier ratings. But still, it's an awfully good program!

Season 3 should have been a focus on the CID team working on a crooked contractions union, similiar to the Dock Workers Union Storyline, and corruption with the senator and then they could have had the tie ins with Stringer and Avon  but still had a new set of interesting characters and a believable storyline.

The third season of The Wire shifts its focus from investigation of the Stevedores' Union (dockworkers) back to the Barksdale and Bell drug ring.  Major Colvin does something quite dramatic and exceedingly unorthodox to control crime by way of controlling drug dealers, and it works shockingly well.  The personal stories of the detectives working on the wire in the major case unit continue to unfold.  Excellent writing, story development and acting.

The show continues to deliver.  Smart, gritty, realistic.
All characters, no matter the amount of screen time devoted them, are developed and given depth.
Fantastic series

From a former police officer. The wire is based on facts of everyday life in Baltimore Maryland the characters names were changed but most events did occur. .

This is the best show ever produced by HBO of all that I have seen to date. I would give it ten stars of I could. I was born in Baltimore and I  have seen for myself the havoc wrecked upon the city. I knew the city when there were no high rises. I saw "redevelopment" ruin this town over and over again. The developers and politicians get rich and the working poor lose what little they have. The situation in Baltimore is repeated time and time again in cities across the United States as industry shuts down and working people can't make ends meet. Oakland, California, Seattle,Washington, Detroit, Michigan, Dayton, Ohio, Pittsburgh,Pennsylvania, and the list goes on. Never have I seen such a compelling portrait of the foul side of human society. This is the equivalent of Greek drama for modern times. This review applies to the first three seasons. We shall see what is it store for the next round.
I did not expect the series to be that much exciting.  You can not trust anyone!  and that what made keep watching.  Main characters can be eliminated any time. Sweet, need more of this

I am not inclined to write a specific number of words in a review.  Particularly when forced.  I would simply say that "The Wire - Season three, just as the other four seasons, appealed to me as a viewer.  It had a down to earth, believable quality to it.  It showed the kind of weaseling, omission, prevarication, and maneuvering that I believe does occur in the government at every level.  Outside of that, it is just good, enjoyable TV.
superb writing and a realistic and depressing look into the drug culture.  a revolving door of crime and punishment for the police detectives and the negative role that politics play
Great show!  I watched all 5 seasons in about 2 weeks.  Filmed like the movie "traffic" but with more humor and levity.  I Loved it!

Incredible series. Nothing else quite like it. I have yet to finish the fifth season, but so far season 2 stands out as 10 stars on a 5 star scale. Absolutely amazing, while the rest is merely fantastic.  The 4th seems like the weaker of them,  but only because what makes the show so interesting (the major crimes unit) is absent for most of it. The incredible acting and realism are there for sure and there is nothing wrong with what they do show.. only with what is missing. So far in my opinion , best to worst are seasons 2,1,3, and finally 4. I am sure season 5 will be amazing being the end and will probably place season 4 in a different context for me. For now ..  This is what stands.
I like this show! I didn't get the chance to see it when it was in rotation. I'm catching up now.

I stumbled across this series and quickly became addicted.  Each season weaves characters in and out as the Baltimore police struggle to bring down the major players in the street level drug scene with stories that overlap between local corruption in politics, the port, the drug gangs and the corruption within the police itself.
Never boring storyline. Reality at its best. Can't stop watching. You will be hooked! Come on go ahead and watch already.
This is what real reality TV is. Superb acting and ambientation makes a fictional work come much closer to reality than you might think.

One of the best police crime series I've ever watched.

do to a city.

Love, Love, Love!!!!!!!!!!!!!!  This is possibly (probably)  the  best series EVER!  I just wish they would come back!
From: Washington State's Green Mountain.

Outstanding TV;  based on : Plot, Characters,  Realist portrayal of the 1980's and life on the streets of a Metro area.  As engaging today 2014 as it was in the 1990's.

Besides being great entertainment, an actual display of USA cities dealing with drugs, crime,  racial issues, and folks moving out to the suburbs.
The majority of the script was predictable and very 70's black gangster stuff. But its entertainment if you've got nonthing else.

I can't say enough about this series. As captivating as "Deadwood", "Breaking Bad" and "Newsroom". An absolutely wonderful
piece of entertainment, down to earth, gritty realism at it's finest. I'm amazed at how well even the youngest characters did in
this production masterpiece. I highly recommend it but not for everyone. Some viewers may be too sensitive to the language and violence to get past that and fully enjoy the series. Furthermore, the infighting and political wrangling inside the department was
graphically demonstrated in a masterful way. I for one congratulate everyone involved in making this series possible. One of the
best ever to be created. Thank You.

The Wire maintains its momentum and brings viewers into opinionated states bordering on becoming judgmental. We may ask ourselves (and shout at the tv screen) that why didn't the political powers do something about it before. Where are the persons responsible for the "hoppers" and the "younguns"? It's a sad state of affairs but unfortunately it's all too true especially in large cities. I can't speak to certain situations without giving away the story. Just watch it, it will make you think, or at least should.

To date, The Wire is the greatest cinematic achievement in the history of the small screen. And thats not the greatest compliment I can give The Wire. The greatest compliment I can give is this: 100 years from now, I believe that statement will still be true. In no small part, because I doubt a vision this ambitious will ever be attempted, much less so fully realized.

Best even series on TV and all elected US officials should be forced to see all five seasons.  Its beyond words.

The novelty of this show is that it changes it's focus of street crimes through a complicated layering system. While it always makes it back to the corner, the show takes you through the different aspects of how and why the corners exist, while maintaining a true assessment of the characters that man them and those that seek to eradicate them. This show also shows the reality of the crimes. Money breeds corruption and drugs are an extension of that corruption on every level. From the corner kids to the cheating police to the corrupt politicians to the suppliers and backers, everyone is corrupt in one way or another. If not for money, for power or fame and no one gets out alive or unharmed in one way or another. The best intentions are corrupted by the need to succeed.

The Wire is an enthralling, thrilling show with lots of action.  We binge watched Season 3 over the Memorial Day weekend, and would definitely do it again.  My only tip would be to consider turning on closed caption during some of the seasons where they are listening to the actual Wire Tap -- it makes it a lot easier to follow whats happening!
i cannot stream all the episodes of the wire,but the program is very good. I am only able to stream one episode.

Also explores the inner machinations of the police force & government officials - everything you thought about the corrupt politicians is correct!  It's a wonder anything ever gets accomplished......But I digress - the show is greatly acted and written.  If you love network tv cop shows, give this a try; it's WAY more realistic.

The best season yet and makes me fully understand why The Wire has such a cult following. This show does a great job of adding new characters into the story while continuing to build on the exploits of the characters introduced in Seasons 1&2.
Riveting, suspenseful, excellent series.the best show in a long time. A must see show. Really keeps you on the edge of your seat.

A deep world with perhaps 40 characters who have substantial roles, but there are many great moments when you are vividly involved in an action, a scene, a dialogue that has enormous impact on your perception of the world of Baltimore police, politics, the street people who inhabit the drug selling life, and the people behind them. I finally got around to watching "The Wire" long after it had completed its run on HBO. All I can say is that this is the finest TV show I've ever seen.  From the outstanding writing through so many stunning performances by a superlative cast, there's never been anything like this on TV.  I'm familiar with Baltimore and have traveled through some of areas portrayed in the series. I was a huge fan of "Homicide: Life on the Street" during its years on network, but "The Wire" ratchets up every aspect of production portraying the depth of characters and making every story it tells count for something.  I've worked my way through seasons 1-3 and my only reluctance to commencing with season 4 is that once I start watching, I want to sit through every episode without a break.  It's that good.

I had to purchase those episodes online from Amazon, which was no big deal, but now I have an incomplete season 3.

The writing is excellent in this television program that examines life in the city of Baltimore, Maryland. What at first seems like a cop shopw later reveals itself to become almost a creation story. Baltimore is presented as a microcosm of the nation where institutions personally affect the people that make up these institutions. It's in this medium that this show's signature realism has its strengths revealed. The narrative style is very straightforward as is the cinematography, but the plot lines are anything but. However, instead of being frustrated by the complexity of the story; the show remains thrilling throughout. This product came very promptly and everything was in the stated condition.

The Third Season of The Wire is television drama at its absolute best. And with Bunny Colvin's "Hamsterdam," it's T.V. at its most groundbreaking and subversive. A major theme--if not *the* major theme throughout the series--is the futility of the so-called "War on Drugs." Here, the show doesn't hold back, with a story that should be required viewing for every citizen whose tax dollars go to maintaining this "war" and the world's largest prison system that it's helped create.

The Wire explores the social, political, educational and ever-changing media environments in a large urban center, Baltimore, MD.  The writing is extraordinary for its prescience, the acting on target.  Dare I say some of the scenes are so powerful as to be Shakespearean.  The greatest tragedy was that the show did not receive the national recognition during its run.  Only after season 5 did the writing garner an Emmy.  Watch all seasons.  Watch them again.  Like modern art, you will see something  new every time.  To quote  Detective Lester Freemon "..All the pieces matter."

Unlike the flaccid Season Two, this one begins with a bang but happily doesn't quite end with a whimper. You'll almost certainly need to watch the first episode at least a couple of times to make sense out of what's going on they have so many expository balls in the air at the same time. After this explosive beginning the show settles down into routine until the last two episodes where stuff starts to happen again. And that's the problem: the season has a huge sag in the middle where the three or four main strands of the story pretty well just tread water. For instance we keep on coming back to "Hamsterdam" where we are shown (again and again and again) controlled chaos in the street, cops standing around muttering in bemused tones, then they go on to something else, then back to Hamsterdam where we are shown controlled chaos in the street, cops standing around muttering in bemused tones, etc; almost exactly the same thing as before. This goes on for episode after episode until it comes time to wrap everything up at the end. And so it goes for all the other storylines: Stringer Bell's frustrated attempts to expand his horizons, McNulty's personal travails, Lestor Freamon's wiretapping endeavours, Tommy Carcetti's councilman-on-the-make manoeuvers, skullduggery and weaseling between the Mayor and Police Commissioner, etc. We keep on coming back and back and back and nothing has changed. Until those last two episodes.....

Throughout the whole season "gritty realism" is laid on by the shovelful to the point where it threatens to become the raison-d'etre of the entire show. Pretty well everyone swears five times as much as they do in real life but, hey, that's HBO, baby! There's an omnipresent crassness to the tone with an obvious "boys will be boys" ironic finger-wagging attitude about the things McNulty and Bunk get up to and which we're obviously meant to find uproarious. I'm all for Animal House-style crudities in their place but these guys just don't have the style for it. It all seems so fake as though the writers have concocted these episodes merely to give an ersatz "colour" to the characters. McNulty - I think - is supposed to be full of roguish charm. I say this because Dominic West (who play-acts his way through the role) keeps pulling faces and assuming expressions pantomimically suggestive of "roguish charm". He's the main weakness in a cast which contains a few excellent performances. Idris Elba as Stringer Bell doesn't seem to be performing at all; he just projects. And Wood Harris (Avon Barksdale) is almost as authentic while Aiden Gillen as Councillor Carcetti does a fine tight-mouthed Dustin Hoffman impression. Perhaps Michael K. Williams as Omar overdoes the "outlaw" element of the character but I love to watch the avenging devil go about creating mayhem.

Anyway, I find it hard not to conclude that this is a ridiculously overrated series in view of raves like "the most perfect thing in the history of television" and "the best show in the history of television". Sure, it's often interesting but the BEST show in the HISTORY of television?!!!!!! My guess for this critical over-enthusiasm?: it offers an educated and probably not overly-streetwise audience the seemingly authentic vicarious thrill of hangin' with the homies without the attendant risk of actually having to do so.

Buying a television series on DVD is generally a wasted investment - once you watch the series rarely will you go back and watch it again. At best it would end up being a secret santa present or a rotating loan between friends and family. The Wire is different and actually worth the investment. The third season shifts the focus back to the Baltimore drug dealers and picks up where Season 1 left off. While the plot and characters specifically related to Season 1 aren't as gripping as the original season, this third season starts to highlight the political scene in Baltimore and incorporates many characters introduced in the second season. As with the first season, the beauty of the show lies in the careful character development and the attention to detail. There are no extra characters who appear in one episode never to be seen again - even the seemingly least important background character will come up again later in the season and again in subsequent seasons. More importantly there are no filler episodes in the season - each one is important to the plot of the season, the overall plot of the series and to the development of major and minor characters.

I wouldn't consider myself a tv junkie or a dedicated fan of crime dramas like Law & Order, but this series is simply too good to miss out on. Watching the season again, particularly after having watched the subsequent seasons, you gain an even greater appreciation for the character development and you pick up on a ton of details that didn't seem important the first time through.

While the first two seasons of this series were excellent, the third really drops off in quality. Much of the story is redundant and the series starts to morally preach rather than tell a realistic story. There is good stuff in the season, but its about half of the content.

The good part of the season is the expansion of the series into the politics of city hall in Baltimore. The strength of the series overall is that it keeps adding to a ever-richer and more comprehensive view of the city by adding institutions and characters to the story. The understanding of how politics work in a city is first rate. The scripts ring true and all of the characters play to type. That is the good.

On the other side, the idea of the wiretap investigation is played out. So is Stringer Bell and Avon Barksdale as characters. So are most of the police characters. There just isn't anywhere new to go with any of this stuff that they have not already done in the first two seasons.

Equally bad is long blocks of the show devoted to lame "message" politics. The show basically plays out a "what if" with regard to legalization of drugs. But its completely contrived, false and idealized. Unlike most of whats in "the wire", everything assoicated with the subplot is basically garbage. Rather than show things in a realistic way as far as the positives and negatives of legalization, they are selling "message". There are ways a police captain might subvert the law for a while and create a defacto legalization of drugs. But the things shown in the wire are not how it would be done. A police captain could create an open-air drug market by selective enforcement. But a police captain could not create an open-air drug market guarded by the police and served by city social services.

The scripts and the acting are all fine. But show stepped down from a high level of realism into preachy television message drama. And it may still be better than 90% of television drama, but the star grade I've given is in terms of the show in competition with itself. And this third season is nowhere near the quality level of the first two seasons. (with the notable exception of the city hall and election portions).
Received in a timely fashion and you already know that this is the best show ever!

It's true what they say..."There are only two kinds of people---those who love The Wire and those who never heard of it. "
All I needed to know about life, I learned from The Wire.  It truly is the best television series ever made.

I started watching The Wire in the Fall of 2009, buying the first season a few months before in an impulse buy fueled purely off word of mouth.  I popped in the first disc to Season One, having no clue that I was about to undertake one of the most enthralling and engaging storylines ever told on any medium.

The first season was transcendent, the second season was even better.  I bought the third season and anxiously awaited the third season in the mail, anticipating (from the cover) that Avon Barksdale would get out of jail and the conflict would resume between the Barksdale faction and the Major Crimes unit of the Baltimore PD.

But what I got most out of season three was disappointment.  The writers turned Barksdale into a caricature, a character bent on revenge who, from the street-smart ringleader we saw in season one, should know better.  I've tried to talk myself out of this point in a desperate attempt to justify Barksdale's need for revenge on Stanfield and his crew. It's obvious the major traffickers in The Wire are obsessed with status and reputation--we see it in season five when Chris had been hiding Omar's defiant challenge to Marlo to meet him in the streets, just to have Marlo throw a tantrum when he finds out that Omar had been calling him out--but it still didn't ring true with me.  I watched the drug dealers work the corners in the first two seasons thinking, "These guys are smart, they know what they're doing, and they are way too level-headed and smart to get caught."

Of course, we see Stringer try to contain him, but that's not the real point for me.  Avon never struck me as a vindictive character in the first season--maybe I got the wrong impression, I've slept a lot since then--but then he is all of the sudden hellbent on popping Stanfield?  Even as a viewer, the last person who should be able to predict what will happen in a season of The Wire, I can see that he will just destroy his empire in blind rage.

Brother Mouzone, while interesting and providing some great comic relief, seems to be another caricature, a cold-blooded killer who sits in the park and reads while waiting for the people he is paid to hit.  His complacency seems almost ridiculous in an environment where the most dangerous stick-up man in Baltimore was gunned down by a kid not even ten years old.  I kept waiting for someone to simply walk up and shoot him--I mean, that's really all it would take, right?

Also unbelievable is Major Colvin's experimentation with legalizing drugs.  Politically, it's a brilliant ploy by the writers to make a point, but not ultimately feasible to incorporate into the story.

Maybe it's my obsession with perfection that makes me consider The Wire in such absolutist terms--I was spoiled on the first two seasons.  To me, everything had to feel perfect.  Absolutely perfect.  And season three wasn't absolutely perfect, although it's still great, and it's really not up to debate that the third season of the show requires us to take the biggest leap of faith with the storytellers.  We have to take more for granted this season than any other season.

The season also picks up in media res, almost forcing the season's storylines on us in the first few episodes.  The other four seasons of The Wire has an inherent momentum to it, but it's not the first episode of the respective season that grabs you by the balls.  Instead, it's a cumulation of the first three or four episodes, all of them streaming together to predict the conflicts and threads that will play out in that season.

Season three makes one thing painfully obvious--the writers had decided before they started writing the season that they were taking the show in a different direction.  Barksdale's downfall seemed forced to move the story to another kingpin, and the legalization of drugs seemed forced to prove points about drugs.  These are not, in the grand scheme of things, cardinal sins, but they do make the season feel less...true.  Because of this, season three primarily serves as a bridge between the first two and last two seasons--a season that foreshadows the downfall of Barksdale and the rise of Stanfield, and continues to delve into the nature of addiction and the inevitability of drug use in America.  I absolutely love this show, but this was easily the weakest season.

Seasons Rank: 4-2-1-5-3

I was turned on to this series long after it's run on HBO ended.  I kept reading so many great things about it, so I had to check it out for myself.  By the end of Season One I was hooked!  The characters are compelling as all hell and by no means the cardboard cutouts one usually associates with television shows (or movies for that matter) dealing with African American drug lords, their enforcers and street sellers. Anyway, if I thought Seasons 1 and 2 were great, they were nothing compared to Season 3.  "Profound" is the only word I can use to describe it - absolutely profound!!!!  I'm in complete awe of the genius of THE WIRE!
