.....HBO series.  I'm not sure what to make of the fact that I passed over this series a few times while browsing shows...it didn't have that instant hook that dragged me into HBO's other outstanding shows like Deadwood, The Sopranos, etc.  But one night I gave it a try and realized that 'the hook' is not what this show is about.....it is too deep and complex.  And that is exactly why it is compelling.  Once you get into the swim of the story you can't look away.  It's unlike anything I've ever seen.  It tackles all the issues that contribute to urban blight: politics, education, crime and interweaves the stories in a way that you start to 'get' the whole tapestry.  There are no saccharine (sp?) moral victories here.  The people we come to care about are in their own swim and are powerless to combat the forces sweeping them along.  It is a show imbued with compassion but no clear cut answers.  I can't recommend it enough..........

I only started watching The Wire because my husband is a huge fan, and let me just say...WOW!  As others have said, this is the absolute best show on tv no doubt about it.  I started with season 3 leading up to season 4 on HBO and I only wanted to see more.  It is raw, gripping, entertaining, and ADDICTIVE.  The only thing this show leaves to be desired is more seasons.

First, "The Wire" is fantastic.  Some of the best and most realistic writing and acting ever seen on television.  Dominic West, Idris Elba, Deirdre Lovejoy, Michael Williams-- they're all fantastic.  I'm sure Jeffrey Lorenzo (whom Amazon is listing as the lead star currently) is fantastic, but I DON'T KNOW WHO HE IS!  Similarly with the entire cast they list... What is up with this?

I have never written a review for anything purchased on Amazon.  However, upon finishing the forth season of The Wire and being a devoted fan of this show since the first season, it is this show that has compelled me to write a review.  Part of the reason is clearly to join in the fun with those whose complete devotion and love for this show is obvious.  Part of it is to help promote a show that lacks in ratings due primarily to the expectations they have of their audience.

But the real reason I am writing this is in the complete off-chance that David Simon cruises Amazon ratings, reads this and listen to me BEGGING HIM to find a way to make this series last beyond a fifth season.

Anyhow- on to the review.  With little doubt, The Wire will take its place among **the world's** greatest fiction ever created.  The Wire deserves a place on the same shelf has Homer's epics, Chaucer's tales and Shakespeare's plays.  My sense is that most who have left their feedback here would not disagree.

The characters in this drama live and work within very real instituations that all of us do.  They work in and around the system to the best of their abilities.  These characters live within organizations that have goals, metrics and lives of their owns that overshadow the individuals that comprise them.  The people are flawed in real and human ways. But every day, they go to work- whether that work happens to fall on one side of the law.

Each scene, each line of dialogue, each camera shot has been deliberately considered.  It is completely evident that David Simon, et.al. are primarily focused on the story.  It's not about what the audience wants or expects.  Of course the situations have been constructed to create a textured, intricate fabric, but the character respond with sincerity to their predicaments.

For those who are not initiated into The Wire- like others, I highly recommend starting with Season 1. Some suggest that it is necessary for future seasons.  I actually disagree with this.  While you will certainly miss some of the nuance in subsequent seasons, it is possible to watch the seasons out of order.

However, the big challenge with this work of fiction is that each subsequent season only becomes more complex than the one before it.  Watching season 1 is in many ways the best way to "dip your toes" into the water as it (surprisingly!) is the least complex of the 4 seasons.  Furthermore, I am going to depart again from my friends, and suggest that the second season is also fairly critical as it establishes a few characters that become key players in later seasons (eg Prop Joe, the Greeks- who I actually suspect will become quite important in Season 5 what with Marlo being introduced to them).  But beyond that, I actually thought Season 2 was quite good on its own.. but sure- certainly not as critical in the story of the Barksdales.

For those who have seen the forth season, it is nothing short of spectacular.  I find myself to have an empty space in my heart now with nothing more left for the season and salivating for the fifth and final one to return.

To the uninitiated, who crave beautifully constructed, flawlessly executed and frighteningly addicting works of fiction... this is masterful literature for our generation.

The third season of The Wire is at least as good as the first two. What a pity we don't have TV of this quality in the UK. But DVDs and Amazon mean that we can watch it anyway. Eat your heart out British Broadcasting Corp!

It's all been said in virtually every other review. This is the most wonderful programme (all seasons) ever created for TV that TV doesn't appear to know about - at least in the U.K. Thanks to HBO for getting behind this great achievement on every level. Each season on DVD is well worth the wait. Seasons 4 and 5 a.s.a.p. please.

People who have seen the previous two seasons of The Wire will agree that the show "cruises" into Season 3.

One of the great things about this show is the continuity of characters and story threads through the whole show.  The Wire doesn't jump out of the TV set and slap you in the face like many current shows (there is nothing wrong with that), it simply surrounds you.  By the end of the season you are intimately familiar with each character and fully understand the story content.  Season 3 gives us surprising, no, shocking confirmation of how today's criminals have the upper hand (in law) and shows the lengths to which the enforcers of our laws have to go to try to bring the criminals to justice.  The usual "untouchables" return this season to peddle their wares but this time, one senior police officer has a unusual (illegal?) method of controlling them and thus cleaning up the streets.  Of course, McNulty & friends are on the periphery with their wire taps of the main "players" and stumble upon the "controlled zone" and have to face the dilemma of fingering a friend or helping.

Is this reality?  Who knows ... I hope not!  Does it feel real with (in my view) Award-Winning performances from both "cop" & "criminal"?  Well...I recommend that you make your own judgement - why don't you buy a copy & decide for yourself.
The quality of the DVD's was good. However I did not like the third season as well as the first two seasons. It seemed that the story was setting up for season 4.

I am a huge fan of The Wire.  I didn't really get into it until the middle of Season 3.  I was so fascinated that I had to purchase the DVDs of Season 1, 2, and 3 to make sure I had seen everything.  I believe that Season 3 is definitely the best thus far.....
Fantastic conclusion to one story line on the best written show to television.

The Wire is easily one of the greatest, if not the greatest, cinematic pieces of art ever.  Potential WATCHERS know this however, this is a show that requires a significant amount of commitment; do not expect to sit back and be entertained.  The show challenges the watcher and requires reflection on an array of intellectual levels.  At a minimum, the reasonably bright should have no problem connecting the scattered dots The Wire's creators masterfully placed for viewers.  The dull on the other hand will only see a show with cops and a group of unintelligible thugs while searching for the quick entertainment fix that can only come from brainless shows like Cops, CSI, or The Shield.

This is the best show on television period. Each season of THE WIRE presents a Dickensian view of Baltimore that nurishes both the heart and mind of the viewer. Like HOMICIDE and THE CORNER, THE WIRE present this beautiful city as its main character.

27 out of 28 reviewers below gave this 5 stars for a reason- this is incredibly good TV.  This is now my favorite series of all, second favorite was "I, Claudius". Both series transcend the medium and make something that is truly great.  Buy this now!

In it's third season, The Wire keeps rollin'.  This year revolves around Avon and Stringer's expansion of their domain into areas other than the drug trade while at the same time new competition is nipping at their heels on the corners.

Once again we get fabulous writing and acting performances with plenty of back-stabbing and blood-letting.

The Wire remains one of, if not the best, programs on television.

I hesitate to try to typify THE WIRE in a wee Amazon review, as the show's extraordinary realism and excellence are reflected in so many different components, it would take a feature article to do it justice. For example, this crime program is populated by police officers and criminals who are in many cases, the "genuine article," and there is no obvious difference between these real-deal folks and the show's ACTUAL actors. Thus, we can score one for verisimilitude.  (Actually, score two.)

I'd also like to point out that if you're a fan of this show and you haven't read teleplay writer and novelist George Pelecanos's work yet, get to it. (Oh, and cancel that holiday you were thinking about spending in Baltimore. The place is apparently a corrupt hellhole.)

There is a scene in the third season of "The Wire" that I think is the best scene of dramatic TV that I have ever seen. It concerns a black detective, talking with the street hoodlum "Omar" about the way the neighborhood used to be, and he says, "you know, no matter how hard people were, there was no such thing as a person that got killed and didn't matter". That scene is a great statement and commentary on American inner cities and what has happened to them. You can see that Omar is trying to "blow it off" and be tough, but in his eyes, you can see that those words have struck him to his core. The scene is one of the best in the entire series and indicative of how good this series is. The writing is absolutely spectacular. It blows me away how good this show is.

Simply put, "The Wire" is the best series on TV, bar none. Individuals weaned on network programming may have a difficult time getting into this series because the story takes time to unfold, spans the entire season--segments are not neatly tied up--and because the writers treat the viewers as though they are intelligent. (I recently purchased Season One of the widely acclaimed "24." It turned out to be everything "The Wire" is not: artificial, contrived, shallow, and an insult to one's intelligence.)

Filmed on location on Baltimore's mean streets, "The Wire" is driven by a rich cast of well-developed, complex, believable characters--politicians, cops, drug lords, street hustlers.  The casting is perfect and the acting some of the best you will see on TV.  I came away from this series feeling that it, more than any other TV programming that I had seen, portrayed both the street drug culture and the war on drugs--especially national, local, and police politics--as it really is.

By the end of Season One, the main character, detective Jimmy McNulty, has run afoul of his superiors, and he is banished from working to bring down the Barksdale drug organization to the Baltimore PD's harbor patrol. This sets the stage for Season Two, which unfolds in the harbor setting and represents a distinct departure from the story line of Season One. Season Two ends with McNulty winning his way back onto the task force targeting Barksdale, setting the stage for Season Three. Thus, Season Three could be considered a continuation of Season One, with Season Two standing on its own. I watched the three seasons in sequence because (then) I had no choice. But if I had access to all three seasons, I'd have been sorely tempted to have gone from Season One to Season Three in my desire to see how the Barksdale story line played out. Then I'd have watched Season Two. This in no way is to meant to knock Season Two--it, too, is excellent--it is simply a reflection of how deeply Season One draws you into its story.  Does Season Three meet the high expectations set by Season One? It exceeded my expectations, and Season Three stands as my favorite of the three. Watch the first season and you will want to own all three (soon four) seasons.

I'd love to delve into all of the facets of "The Wire," but there just isn't enough space.

What I can say is thank Jeebus that it's coming back for another season (just heard about its renewal for a fifth and, I believe, final season).

To try and encapsulate what the third season is about really will not do it justice, but the focus is certainly back on the streets. Avon Barksdale, having schemed his way into an early release from Jessup Correctional, is coming back home, where his right-hand man, the magnetic, engaging Stringer Bell, has been running so serious a business that he can buy legit cribs for himself and Avon; in fact, one of the beauty moments in this season is seeing Stringer's business-man persona put in check when he tries his hand at political persuasion.

The central struggle, as usual, is the drug trade: mandates are coming from the department to reduce crime OR ELSE. One particularly affecting scene is watching the mayor and police commissioner debate, almost glibly, about how many homicides it will take before the two experience political fallout ("300 is too many... now, if you can do 275...? That's something we can live with."). You could tell this season that politics and political figures are going to have a much bigger role in future episodes. The cutthroat race for mayor, I think, is really going to heat up in the next season.

And it's no fair to spill the biggest surprise of the season, even though it's just a one-second shot of Captain Rawls. Can't WAIT to see what they do with THAT in the fourth season.

I'm not sure if there's any way a police commander could get away with what Maj. Bunnie Colvin tries to get away with in this season, but it's certainly an interesting take on fighting the violence that often accompanies the drug war.

Add in a healthy dose of my main man Omar, turf beef with a young up-and-comer in the drug trade and the death of a character who will be universally missed, and you have another volatile, staggeringly earnest portrayal of class conflict, the war on drugs and, in creator David Simon's words, 'the America that America doesn't need.'

HBO may charge two arms and a leg for their series (personally, I prefer to rent 'em on Netflix), but if one is worth it, it's "The Wire."

A little denial on my part . I caught one show of the wire in the  first season. I liked it so much I decided to surf for reviews of the cast and plot.  After reading here, all the good reviews and  rotten tomatoes, IMDB, ect. I purchased season one. I now have three season . And I do not want it to end.  Ever, period . This collective is perhaps the most entertaining dialogue rich graphic urban grit of photography ever on any screen . Just is and amazing  combinations  of good people bad people, intertwined . Everything just came together in these  work's. If you have the attention span of a six year old it might be just a little urban eye candy. Pay attention this series  blazes  A true light in the cinematic hinterlands. I wanna give it a ^6
EVERYTHING YOU SEE IN THIS DVD IS WHAT IS REALLY GOING ON IN MY CITY

I'm writing this on a Monday morning, having just finished a weekend-long marathon viewing of Season 3 with my wife to prepare for Season 4. This tells you two things about "The Wire":

1. **You need to pay attention.** That's a scarce commodity these days - which is why the show will never be as big a ratings hit as it deserves. And I'm sure I'll lose this product more sales than I gain when I boast how a critical plot development in Season 3 will make little sense if you didn't watch Season 1. [Or at least carefully read the episode summaries on HBO's web site.] But that's the kind of show it is - where you learn a very surprising (and telling) fact about one of the two dozen or so major supporting characters by a wordless two-second shot at the end of a scene that was about a different sub-plot entirely. Also: the thick street accents and liberal use of gangsta and police slang will probably have you hitting the Rewind button on your DVD remote more than once.

2. **You will enjoy paying attention.** [I'll bet that no one would be willing to watch 12 episodes of, say, "Without A Trace" in three days.] Although its fellow HBO show "Deadwood" is the one noted for the savory richness of its dialogue, one could argue that "The Wire" is equally eloquent - though unprintable - while being a little less precious about it. Just about every episode has at least one speech so strong that it will echo in your mind long after the hour is over. And the acting is equally and uniformly splendid, fully inhabiting three-dimensional characters who make almost impossible a facile assortment into "good" and "bad" columns.
This is without question the best show on television, hands down.  It's beyond me why so many people gravitate to HBO's other shows and overlook this gem.  Don't make the same mistake!

The Wire has made me laugh harder, cry harder, and think harder than anything else I've sever seen or read.

No other movie or TV show even begins to approach the dramatic scope of this show. The divisions between episodes and seasons are merely logistic - it's all continuous - a brilliantly conceived drama of epic, Shakespearian proportions.

Season 1 was so powerful unto itself, and yet now we see that every scene in it was critical to the next two seasons.

For example, the character of Brianna, D'Angelo's mother, appears briefly in each  season, but everything she does and says is pivotally important. When she and McNulty come face to face in Season III it's so powerful that it's like getting slugged in the stomach - and this sets up an even more devastating scene between Stringer and Avon, and yet another between Stringer, Avon and Brianna. The honesty and power of the acting is astounding.

If The Wire has lower ratings than lesser shows such as The Sopranos, it's because it's so meticulous in avoiding any type of sensationalism, clich, or predictability. The first 3 episodes of each season are slow and full of details, but if you watch them several times, they set you up later for the type of emotional payoff that you will simply not find elsewhere.

That's the massive payoff in the third season here, a real look at what we would see around us were we to abandon the "war on drugs" ... the good, bad, and ugly of it.

This has been the best show on TV for a while.  It's a slightly difficult view because each episode is like a chapter is a novel, without introduction at the start and climax near the end.  Anyone who sticks with it, who undertakes the reading of the entire book, is rewarded massively.  I'm convinced it's the best drama television has seen to date.

Superlatives fail to describe the excellence of this series.  If you enjoy the degree of realism in "The Sopranos", "Six Feet Under", or "The Shield" - three other shows that have aspired to a high level of realism and sophistication - check this out.

After a virtuosic first season and an ambitious (but not quite as thrilling) second season, The Wire's third season proved to be the best one yet. Even though it hasn't been embraced by the public at large (like, say, The Sopranos), the show has received gobs of critical acclaim and delivers the goods, too, every week. I think that not only is The Wire a better show than The Sopranos (which is, admittedly, a truism), but it is a show which better reflects our post-9/11 mindset than its erstwhile New Jersey neighbor. The Sopranos is a product of another time, the zeitgeist of the late 1990s, with its constant putdowns of moneyed, whining, shrink-visiting, latte-sipping, politically-correct hipsters (the Eagles song "Get Over It" being perhaps the definitive cultural manifesto of the time). That show produced three excellent seasons of TV, but then 9/11 changed the world and Tony, Paulie, et al, never managed to get back ahead of the curve. The Wire was formed in direct response to 9/11 and links the drug war to the War on Terror, in both a direct and indirect sense, while examining the institutions (both legitimate and seamy) and the individuals that inhabit them. Although the show is described (even by itself) with such terms as "gritty" and "unvarnished", it is actually not so simple--in the show, as in life, few people fall into the sinner and saint categories. Leaders in these institutions are generally rational and even the antagonists occasionally speak uncomfortable truths. The result is a universe in which we find people's character defined not by their social or economic position.

Season 3 builds on the previous seasons and returns to the streets for a showdown between Avon Barksdale's (Wood Harris) crew (still managed, in the interim, by Stringer Bell (Idris Elba)) and a vicious upstart by the name of Marlo, who has taken control of Avon's territory thanks to Stringer's attempts to go straight. On the law side, Kima's (Sonja Sohn) doubts about motherhood continue to grow, while newly-minted Deputy Commissioner Rawls (John Doman) rips district commanders to shreds (and is the subject of a revelation of some interest). At the center of it all is Jimmy McNulty (Dominic West), whose liaison with an elite political consultant leads to some quite surprising conclusions that make you reevaluate the character entirely. The political plotline leads naturally into the new arena the show explores, Baltimore's city politics, which prominently features two figures: Mayor Clarence Royce, who seems like an honest, reasonable man, and City Councilman Tommy Carcetti (Adrien Gillen), whose character flirts the line between raw ambition and occasional idealism. In between these personalities is still-Acting Commissioner Burrell (Frankie Faison), whose previous cock-of-the-walk status gives way to getting chewed out by the Mayor. There are plenty more great storylines: Daniels (Lance Reddick) hooking up with Pearlman (and dealing with his nominal wife), Bunk trying to find a wounded officer's gun, and Major "Bunny" Colvin deciding to legalize drugs in condemned areas in order to keep the dealers off the streets. Colvin's plan does reduce crime, and things seem to be getting better, except that the legal drug area ("Hamsterdam") is a hellhole, and eventually the plan is exposed. This plotline just goes to show how much bigger problems can get if they're ignored. Overall, a spectacular season from a show that exceeds even high expectations.

No doubt about it: this is the best written, best produced, best acted television show ever made. Each season, "The Wire" moves from strength to strength, resulting in a powerful ensemble work in which each character is given their due, and every scene has purpose and dramatic heft.  I'm a fan of a lot of classy shows -- "Buffy," "Six Feet Under," "Deadwood," "Freaks And Geeks," "Lost," "America's Next Top Model" -- but none of them has had such a consistent track record.  There hasn't been a slack or weak episode of "The Wire" yet, and the show just gets better and better.  Comparing it to "The Sopranos," for example, I'm shocked by how far down Tony and his crew have fallen off my radar... HBO allowed that show to devolve into a sitcom, whereas "The Wire" remains a taut, intelligent and richly clever drama... There's humor, too, but this show has real impact and depth.

I'm just bummed I have to wait so long to see Season Four!

I believe those of us who have to wait for the DVD releases of The Wire ( which arrive on HBO's typical tortoise-like schedule) are even more amply rewarded than those who watch it on TV. Watching a season of The Wire on DVD is like spending time reading a good novel, and you can watch it at your own pace . ( In my case, over 2 days)

The Wire is simply one of the best shows on TV. That said, I found season 3 somewhat disappointing in comparison the the brilliant first 2 seasons. The new aspect of Baltimore city life explored in season 3- city government/politics- is not as compelling as the  drug business/police storyline of season 1 and the dockworkers/international gangsters plot of season 2.

The new characters introduced are not as compelling, either. The Bunny Colvin character is  appealing and well-acted, but his storyline is too predictable. The Carcetti character felt like a placeholder, as  his story arc didn't go much of anywhere. He will likely  become more significant in season 4, but too much time was wasted  on setting him up. The "Cutty" character's story was just plain boring. I'd  have preferred that  it be cut entirely  in order to expand other elements .

While multiple characters and storylines were ably juggled in season 2, the writers seem  a bit overwhelmed with the new additions. Our old friends from season 1 and 2 get little attention and developments for their characters seem very rushed and  perfunctory ( "Prez "'s  in particular) And  is there ever enough Omar?

The main problem with season 3 is that it is less a complete and satisfying season than  a  wrap up  of plotlines from seasons 1 and 2 and setup for season 4.

However, I was still happy to spend 12 hours in this world, and I can't wait to see what happens next.

Watch The Wire, buy the DVDs, keep this great show going.

It's criminal the amount of people that watch the best drama on television, "The Wire." I started watching because of David Simon. The man wrote the book that ultimately became my favorite TV show of all time, "Homicide: Life on the Street." I quickly became a huge fan, and theres a number of reasons why.

The writing for "The Wire" is nothing short of incredible. It's not written by "TV Writers" but more experienced authors and this makes quite a difference. A season of The Wire unfolds like a great novel. As each episode goes by, the greater the story builds. Its full of amazing characters and has many special touches and little nuances that are a joy to watch. The cast is fantastic and all the actors do a wonderful job.

I think what many people tend to miss is the importance of the storylines and the issues that David Simon and his team are addressing. In season 3 the storyline of Major Bunny Colvin "decriminalising" drugs in a certain area of his district was an amazing look at the world of crime and drugs. It was such an incredible storyline, because it wasn't black and white. An amazing hypothetical that leaves me thinking to this day.

The Wire is television at its very best, it also demands a lot from the viewer. Its definitely worth repeat viewing of the episodes. If you put the time in to notice the detail of the show it is extremely rewarding. The intricate storylines, complex characters, and revealing insights into life and instituitions are waiting for your viewership. This DVD is a must own.  Season 4 of The Wire premieres in Spetember on HBO.

The Wire is by far the best show on HBO. Carnivale is, or should I say was another. Both of these shows do not get the credit they're due. The Sopranos used to be a good show. Now it's just garbage, and the sad thing is that the writer knows that no matter what he puts out, it's still going to beat out shows like the Wire or Carnivale. If you have a job that deals with politics, you will definitely be able to relate to the Wire. Put the stereotype out of your mind that it's just an extended rap video, and watch it. You'll see that you have more in common with the characters than you think. Also check out Carnivale. You'll ask yourself why you haven't been watching these shows all along.

As the third season of HBO's brilliant and innovative the Wire begins, it becomes apparent that the war on drugs in Baltimore is primed to explode.  The previous season, most of the show was focused on events surrounding the docks, but with season three, the series is shifted back to the streets as both sides of the war on drugs escalate to new methods in an effort to eliminate one another, and it's a war that no one is winning.  Avon Barksdale (Wood Harris) is out of jail and looking to reclaim what's his, even if it means going head to head with Stringer Bell (the excellent Idris Elba).  In the meantime, Detective Jimmy McNulty (Dominic West) finds his own life falling to pieces more and more, but it won't stop him from doing what he feels he needs to do.  Featuring a large ensemble cast, all of whom leave a lasting impretion (from Frankie Faison to Lance Reddick), the Wire is one of those rare accomplishments in the world of television that does so much right that it can't be put into words.  The Sopranos and other shows always get the spotlight from the real gems on HBO, and the Wire is one of those shows that deserves much more recognition than it's ever gotten.  If you don't believe that, the proof is right here, and soon enough, the much anticipated fourth season will be premiering, and upon viewing this season, you'll be salivating for it.

I must say after season 2 where they spent most of their time focusing on the docks, Season 3 crept in and just exploded The Wire right back where Season one left off.

I mean how much more drama can a crime/thriller give than what Season 3 gave us.  I mean I Tivo'd the whole season and still watch the reruns that are currently on.  That's when you know a show is just that good.

And the excitement builds to until the very end and like any good show leaves you feening like a junkie for Season 4.  I'm not going to give you all details of the show but I do have my favorite characters as well.  Stringer was my man for real.  Not only was he smooth as hell, but he just was downright cruddy and dirty.  The elements all bad guys need to have.  Omar, well what can you say, a gangsta with a touch of wit.  You can't buy that kind of script anywhere.  McNulty, well he just basically gives a performance of what real Detectives/Cops are, loyal to no one but themselves and will use any method (legal or illegal, mostly the latter) to get who they are after.  And of course Wood Harris as Avon, I couldn't think of a better person to play AVON.  And the cat who plays Avon's right hand man and head of security detail (Big Slim) is hilarious.  "You on a Barksdale corner Homie, we got your back.  Ya Feel Me?"

For a long time nothing could come close to the excellence of HOMICIDE:LIFE ON THE STREETS. That NBC drama was the best police drama on television for many years. Though it faltered in the last few seasons the worst episode was better than the best Law and Order. Nothing on network tv has come close.

Thankfully we are no longer slaves to the whims of the networks. HBO has earned it's rep for great shows and although it isn't the best known, the Sopranos gets that title, in another three or four years, *yawn* it will be back on. While some wait for the next season of the most overrated show on HBO (yeah I said it, the Sopranos is overrated, it bores me) those in the know are eager for the fourth season of HBO's best drama; THE WIRE which starts in Sept, 06.

Season three sees the effects of the Baltimore drug war built to a climax as old cops realize that their lives need more meaning than the next case and old criminals begin to turn on each other.

If you watched the first two seasons you DO NOT want to miss this one. Big changes are in store for both sides of the war on the streets. A Police lieutenant tired of the killing essentially legalizes drugs in his district and guess what? It works!

Stringer Bell tries to go legit but has trouble convincing Avon Barksdale, just back from prison, that the gun should be set aside for the briefcase. Omar is of course, a thorn in the paw for the dealers and the police. Det. Jimmy McNulty is...well, what can you say but he is on the case and all that entails both good and bad.

The ensemble cast is steller, there is not a weak actor in the group and it is tough to say who stand out the most. It is a CRIME that this show doesn't consistantely win (or at least get nominated) for every emmy except best comedy. If you like HBO's commitment to quality leave Jersey and check out Baltimore!

Easily the best drama on television.  At this point it's definitely better than the Sopranos.  Although a big Sopranos fan, the Sopranos has managed to fall off a bit in it's last two seasons (somewhat understandable, they've had a long run).  The Wire is a great show that everyone should be watching, the only reason everyone isn't watching is that they're too busy watching shows about nothing (american idol, entourage, the oc, laguna beach, nip/tuck).  Whatever your self-indulgent guilty pleasure may be, The Wire is worth your while...you'll be entertained and you might even gain some perspective.

This show captures, with painful detail, exactly how I encountered major metropolitan policing for the many years i served in a large city police department (not Baltimore but nearly identical). From investigations with messed up priorities to rank juggling the "stats" and screwing up cases because their only job was to keep the numbers "low" for Monday-morning COMSTAT meetings, this show brings back some of the highs and lows of city police work. All of it is true to the detail.

Not only for this episode but for the entire series. Those who say this is the best television show ever produced are right, right right.  I understand it better after watching interviews with David Simon. I caught on to it late - just this month - and so glad I did.
Bought for a friend to complete his "wire" collection - he's really happy with the series!

The Wire (2002-2008) is excellent. It paved the way for an even better drug crime show, Breaking Bad (2008-2013).

Most people are aware of corporate espionage and what some companies will do to protect their secrets. In the TV show Breaking Bad the two main characters, Walter White, played by Bryan Cranston, and Jesse Pinkman, played by Aaron Paul, possess the knowledge and skill to produce the best meth on the market. And their brand is easily identifiable by its unique blue color.

Several competing criminal organizations buy their services and try to replicate their product but Whites and Pinkmans skill in the art and science of making their blue meth product isn't easily duplicated. One group tries to hold Pinkman hostage in Mexico because their highly trained scientists cant make meth as well as he does. Near the end of the series another criminal group keeps Pinkman chained in their lab and force him to make meth for them because their guy, who worked with both White and Pinkman, is unable to duplicate Pinkmans and Walter Whites skill in the art and science of making their blue meth brand.

Breaking Bad has one of the best story and character arcs ever used in a TV show, which is why it has an IMDb rating of 9.5, right up there with Game of Thrones, another great show. The Wire (2002-2008) was as good as the Sons of Anarchy (2008-2014), but not as good as Breaking Bad. I won't give away the ending of Breaking Bad, but if you watch the complete series, from the first episode to the last, the ending will make complete sense and be very satisfying. Its terrific.

If the above series don't sound interesting here are a few of the series I really enjoyed watching more than once: Band of Brothers (2001), Battlestar Galactica (2004-2009), Black Sails (2014-2017), Cowboy Bebop (1998), Downton Abbey (2010-2015), Firefly (2002), Game of Thrones (2011-2019), The IT Crowd (2006-2013), Jericho (2006-2008), Lonesome Dove (1989), Lost (2004-2010), Merlin (2008-2012), Pride and Prejudice (1995), Rome (2005-2007), Spartacus: Gods of the Arena (2011), Stargate: SG-1 (1997-2007), Stargate: Atlantis (2004-2009), Star Trek The Original Series (1966-1969) and Star Trek Voyager (1995-2001). I didn't list any contemporary series Im following that don't have an end date yet, not conducive to binge watching from beginning to finish, or the hundreds of other fantasy and science fiction shows Ive watched.

If you like reading try some of my favorite authors: Richard Adams, Palo Bacigulupi, Suzanne Collins, Abe Evergreen, Diana Gabaldon, Hugh Howey, George Martin, Brandon Sanderson, John Scalzi, and Andy Weir.

Intrigue, suspense, classic good-versus-evil.  I loved season three - why?  The acting was so real, and because of that, at least for a minute, you started to envision and kinda feel, what life is like when you are in "The game".  Whether you were a fan of Stringer, Barksdale, Marlo or Lt. Daniels and his crew, one thing is for certain "The Game" always wins.  Season three taught all of us that "The Game" continues even after it takes out the gangster, the hard-head, the street-smart and the businessman - eventually, just like in every business, people come, and people go, but work continues to take place because demand "for product" pushes things forward.
Great series
Excellent!! Action pack, surprised. The production should make a 6th season of the Wire, because it ended kind of incomplete,  but overall it was interesting and provocative.
Product was shipped promptly. The product was as described.

This was a good series, some great acting.  In the one about the docks they killed off the best actor.  In the next one, they killed off one of my favorites, even if he was a 'bad' guy.  They keep killing off some of the most interesting and strongest characters.  Pretty reckless.  Also, a lot is going on, and especially in season 3, it was hard to follow a lot of the action, at least for me.
Great Season for the Wire Series!!
